number.text: In this tutorial, I'll show you what parallax mapping is and how you can use it in combination with normal maps

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: in order to get some really nice details out of your surfaces.

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: Now imagine we want a nice 3D wall with actual geometry that looks like this.

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: To achieve that, we would need a height map and a plane with a lot of triangles in it.

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: The problem with that is that we might need thousands or tens of thousands of triangles

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: for this one single plane, but we can't really have that since it would tank our performance.

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: So what if I told you that the brick wall you're looking at right now is made out of just two

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: triangles? Pretty cool, right? Okay, so here's how parallax mapping works.

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: First of all, we still need a height map for this. It's just that instead of displacing

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: actual geometry, we'll simply fake it in the fragment shader. Now you'd initially think of

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: faking it above the surface. The problem with that though is that this plane can only display

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: things on its own surface. So areas like this would get cut off and ruin the illusion.

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: So we will instead be inverting the height map and fake the depth behind the plane.

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: Now how do we do this? Well here at depth 0, we have our plane. Then underneath 8,

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: we have our theoretical height map, meaning you can't actually see it. It's there just in the

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: maths. We are currently sampling point a, but what we really want to sample is point b,

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: since that's the height we're supposed to see. The problem is we can't just calculate b using

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: a formula or something like that. We need to somehow get an approximation for it. To do that,

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: we can simply take the height we're currently at and multiply that by the inverse of our view vector

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: calling this vector s. Since most height maps don't have insanely drastic changes in their height

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: from one point to the next, this gets us somewhat close to our point. Of course this also means that

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: if we do have a steep displacement, then we will be way off with our guess and things will look

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: weird. The problem is that this technique will have inconsistent results depending on the height map.

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: Especially if you look at it from a small angle because then point a is really far away from point b

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: and so assuming there are somewhat close in height is not going to work. So we actually need to

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: modify this a bit. What if instead of getting the height of a and multiplying that with the inverse of v,

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: we simply have multiple levels of height we check. We are essentially going to scale the s vector

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: from a small length to a larger one until we get it underneath the surface. At which point we

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: will sample that pixel to get the color and all that stuff. We can further improve this by averaging

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: the heights of the s that is underneath the surface and the s right before it to get a more accurate

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: result. We can also use geo linear instead of geo nearest when loading the textures to get even

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: smoother results. Now let's put this in practice. We'll continue off from the normal maps tutorial

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: since we need a tbn matrices to work in the textures space. We first want to add the displacement

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: type of texture to our texture class. Then we want to load in the displacement map, bind it and send

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: it off to the fragment shader. Now in the fragment shader we'll load it in and the first thing we'll

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: want to do is to get the view direction and normalize it. Then we'll set the height scale which

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: will control the maximum depth of the illusion and set the amount of layers we are going to check.

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: Notice how I choose the number of layers dynamically based on the angle to the surface. Then we get

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: the s vector. Here I divide it by its set value which will give more dramatic and interesting results.

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: You can opt out of doing this division. Now I just write the logic for checking each layer

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: and after that I interpolate between the current and previous height values. All that's left to do

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: is to discard all fragments that are outside the range of the texture since they look weird

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: and use the UVs in the textures. Now if you run your program you should have a nice 3D brick wall.

number.title: Parallax Occlusion Mapping.mp4
number.text: Don't forget to check out my discord channel and maybe support me on Patreon. As always the source

text: In this tutorial, I'll show you what parallax mapping is and how you can use it in combination with normal maps in order to get some really nice details out of your surfaces. Now imagine we want a nice 3D wall with actual geometry that looks like this. To achieve that, we would need a height map and a plane with a lot of triangles in it. The problem with that is that we might need thousands or tens of thousands of triangles for this one single plane, but we can't really have that since it would tank our performance. So what if I told you that the brick wall you're looking at right now is made out of just two triangles? Pretty cool, right? Okay, so here's how parallax mapping works. First of all, we still need a height map for this. It's just that instead of displacing actual geometry, we'll simply fake it in the fragment shader. Now you'd initially think of faking it above the surface. The problem with that though is that this plane can only display things on its own surface. So areas like this would get cut off and ruin the illusion. So we will instead be inverting the height map and fake the depth behind the plane. Now how do we do this? Well here at depth 0, we have our plane. Then underneath 8, we have our theoretical height map, meaning you can't actually see it. It's there just in the maths. We are currently sampling point a, but what we really want to sample is point b, since that's the height we're supposed to see. The problem is we can't just calculate b using a formula or something like that. We need to somehow get an approximation for it. To do that, we can simply take the height we're currently at and multiply that by the inverse of our view vector calling this vector s. Since most height maps don't have insanely drastic changes in their height from one point to the next, this gets us somewhat close to our point. Of course this also means that if we do have a steep displacement, then we will be way off with our guess and things will look weird. The problem is that this technique will have inconsistent results depending on the height map. Especially if you look at it from a small angle because then point a is really far away from point b and so assuming there are somewhat close in height is not going to work. So we actually need to modify this a bit. What if instead of getting the height of a and multiplying that with the inverse of v, we simply have multiple levels of height we check. We are essentially going to scale the s vector from a small length to a larger one until we get it underneath the surface. At which point we will sample that pixel to get the color and all that stuff. We can further improve this by averaging the heights of the s that is underneath the surface and the s right before it to get a more accurate result. We can also use geo linear instead of geo nearest when loading the textures to get even smoother results. Now let's put this in practice. We'll continue off from the normal maps tutorial since we need a tbn matrices to work in the textures space. We first want to add the displacement type of texture to our texture class. Then we want to load in the displacement map, bind it and send it off to the fragment shader. Now in the fragment shader we'll load it in and the first thing we'll want to do is to get the view direction and normalize it. Then we'll set the height scale which will control the maximum depth of the illusion and set the amount of layers we are going to check. Notice how I choose the number of layers dynamically based on the angle to the surface. Then we get the s vector. Here I divide it by its set value which will give more dramatic and interesting results. You can opt out of doing this division. Now I just write the logic for checking each layer and after that I interpolate between the current and previous height values. All that's left to do is to discard all fragments that are outside the range of the texture since they look weird and use the UVs in the textures. Now if you run your program you should have a nice 3D brick wall. Don't forget to check out my discord channel and maybe support me on Patreon.
